at great elevations.
On the merits of those parts of
the Paper which relate to Geology 
& Botany, I do not profess to 
give an opinion, but I could not 
avoid noticing the great advantage 
derived from photography in giving 
exactness of form and of linear 
proportions to the representation of 
geological and botanical objects.
Although I approve of the 
contents of the Paper generally, I 
think that in some particulars 
it requires alteration. I have 
made a pencil note opposite to 
p. 24 of Vol. 8, where it ap-
pears to me that an inference 
drawn from facts relating to the 
spectrum is incorrectly stated. The 
character of the Paper is in some 
parts too theoretical and argu-
mentative, and would be im-
proved by partaking more of 
the nature of a Report. It was hardly 
possible that a residence of two
